Posts.Content: Lemonsoda wrote: I am on my second round of Xeloda and Tykerb, but my billirubin is so high that mu onc wants me to stop the Tykerb. She suspects that it's the Tykerb doing this not the Xeloda, but we're continuing with the Xeloda, so wait and see. I'm so disappointed as the Tykerb is a great back-up for the Herceptin , which I'm also continuing with. I'm worried that one of my best options for a longer survival is now lost. By the way, she's sure that it's not the cancer that's doing this, as I recently had a scan, and there was no active cancer in my liver thanks to SIRT. Have any of you other Her2+ ladies experienced this? ER/PR+ Her 2+ Diagnosed Stage IV July2011 Dx 7/7/2011, Stage IV, Grade 2, 7/14 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2012 05:04AM Lemonsoda wrote: But, Pizzadad, everything which is now mainstream began in a lab with a mouse. If nobody went on trials, there would be no drugs. I have just got back from US to UK where I took part in a Phase 1 trial using modified T cells. Not expecting a miracle cure, or necessarily any benefit whatsoever, but delighted to be part of an exciting project and happy to support the research MD who has a brilliant idea.
Posts.Title: alternative treatments soleil505 Lemonsoda

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 02:56AM Lemonsoda wrote: I had numerous mets to the liver when diagnosed Stage 4, with one solitary tiny met to my T12 (spine) and one lymph node. There was no possibility of surgery. I am not a fan of resection as I have seen too many posts from ladies who have had their mets return in a very short time. Also the recovery time after the surgery is so long that it might make any other treatment difficult. Last year I researched other options of local treatment to the liver, and finally got SIRT done (Theraspheres) in August. this has shown itself to be an effective treatment for liver mets, and can be repeated if neccessary after a year. The recovery time is very quick as well. My last scan in December showed a complete metabolic response. Next scan is in a few weeks time.  There are some other options for liver mets, such as chemoembolisation and chemo saturation (fairly new). Also don't forget that there are many women on these boards that have been NED in the liver after chemo alone. The thought of a liver resection can be tempting, but in my opinion, it carries a lot of risks! Anne

Posts.Content: May 10, 2013 11:46PM Lemonsoda wrote: If the only scan done was this one, then you don't know that she didn't have more metastases before the treatment started. So don't assume it was useless.  Herceptin will continue to be given from know on to your mother. It may clear up this nodule completely or keep her stable for a long time. I have added Tykerb in with my Herceptin, and I am nearly two years out and leading a goog quality of life. There are also many more treatment options available to your mother. No need for despair!

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 03:21AM Lemonsoda wrote: Oh Laurie, just going through a bit of a low myself. I'm very good at staying strong most of the time, then something will trigger the panic button, and then I go into a downhill spiral. I found out yesterday that although the majority of my liver tumours remain stable, one has grown almost 2cm, and she is considering giving it a blast of RFA. Of course I should be placated by that, but I loved the stable boy, and the loss of him is hard to bear. I didn't want to get out of bed today. One of my friends, a survivor of gastric cancer - his wife also survived the same disease - told me recently that he thought I would be a long term survivor "because of my fantastic attitude," and I think there is something in this. I am not suggesting that anyone who dies is in some way weak willed. Far from it, as we all know that this disease is a beastly relentless killer, but the point that I am making is that when I keep my head, I am more resourceful, more ready to find ways forward. This is one of the ways I keep myself from sinking. I tell myself "Stay in control. Find an answer. There must be one outside there somewhere." When we are distracted and not thinking about the disease, we are not in denial, not any more than any other mortal thinks about death. We are just living our lives. I know this sounds like another of those irritating cliches that people subject us to. But I enjoy the time out. Being grief ridden and afraid is exhausting. Sometimes this is where I'm at. But I don't think I could ever do acceptance. Being in a calm frame of mind enables me to fight. I hope I will do so for as long as I am alive. Don't know if any of this helps answer you question, Laurie, but it helps me to focus on my strategies. Oh what horrible weather today! Anne

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2012 03:08AM Lemonsoda wrote: Hi all, diagnosed a year ago with mets to axilla, one spinal and multiple liver. My onc would not give me a life expectancy, but she said think three years upwards. New onc (various reasons) said be prepared to live many years. She also said she has several patients with similar mets to mine  living 8yrs plus. I asked her even Her2. She said especially Her2 as the drugs are so effective. Right now, axilla clear, T12 spine met resolved, and liver mets stable (3 zapped with RFA). Going to appt for Theraspheres later today, for the liver, but it's just a first appt, so not a foregone conclusion. I just got back from a trip to Florence, Italy, and had a great time, did not think about cancer at all. I try not to be too presumptious about things, but I do not want to waste the good times being miserable. Anne

Posts.Content: Lemonsoda wrote: I had my meeting with my onco today to review the results of my CT/PET 12 weeks after SIRT to my liver. No active cancer! Complete metabolic response! THEN, she told me that there is a new lymph node involved, which has grown a lot bigger, and shows considerable takeup on the PET scan. Also, an axiliary node, which had been resolved earlier this year is now showing activity again. I was so upset. I had so wanted a little peace, a little respite from all this trauma. Now, we are going to start Xeloda and Tykerb as soon as possible, to try to resolve these issues, and prevent any new ones from occuring. Problem was, she explained to me, the Herceptin wasn't quite up to the job any more. This distresses me, as I had hoped to stay stable on it for many years. Now, the future suddenly looks much more precarious. But I'm very glad I did the SIRT. Otherwise I think I would have quite a few more problems on my plate. Anne ER/PR+ Her 2+ Diagnosed Stage IV July2011 Dx 7/7/2011, Stage IV, Grade 2, 7/14 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2013 11:17AM Lemonsoda wrote: Dear beautiful Ebru, take a break from the boards then come back. I am distressed when I read about anyone passing, and often take a break for a few days. But I have learned so much that is invaluable from these boards, so I keep on coming back. Two examples, I found out about a Phase 1 trial in the US from here, and actually got myself on it. (I am in UK). Then I learned about Theraspheres here, and pushed for the procedure, and had it done last August. Made a massive difference to my liver - as of last scan, no active cancer there. We learn from each other's research here, and it can make a difference to our survival. So, hope to see you back soon!

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 03:44AM Lemonsoda wrote: Tilly, don't do the guilt thing. Re visiting relatives, if you don't feel up to it, then just don't do it. Why the hell should you? Yes, I totally agree, they're in their 80s and have had their fair innings (for the US girls, this is an English cricketing term!). We have had unfair hands dealt to us, and if they can't see that, they are very selfish. It's about you now, and in my experience, you should put yourself first because nobody else does. Oh dear, I'm beginning to rant now. Re the childminder. I would be pragmatic here. If she is reliable, I would probably stick with her, as worries about picking up the kids etc are the last thing you need. Is she human enough to have a chat with her about your illness and the way she talks about it? She sound as though her brain and her mouth are not in synch. On the other hand if you've had enough of her, give her her marching orders. Again, no guilt necessary. Anne
Posts.Title: Sorry - this is a rant Tillycat marywh

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 06:45AM Lemonsoda wrote: Hold on here! Eating a nutritious diet high in antioxidants is especially important when having chemo, as at all other times. Green tea is high in antioxidants, and drunk in large quantities by billions of people worldwide. It has no contra-indications on the packet, such as "do not consume when having chemo". I drank it throughout chemo when Stage 2 and continued to do so up to and during chemo for Stage 4. I refuse to torture myself with the idea that my cancer would not have returned if I had not done this. Every nutritionist has their own theories, but I doubt they are as well qualified as oncologists who would surely warn us if doing something as simple as having a cup of tea would scupper their best efforts! Tea is a leaf growing on a bush, a vegetable, for goodness sake. I don't think it's going to undo the effects of taxotere! If it did, I think we would all know about it!
Posts.Title: My Cancer Diet stagefree ShetlandPony

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2011 06:07AM Lemonsoda wrote: Hi Nancyh, I was very disappointed with my first CT scan after 6 rounds of taxotere. It showed very little regression, although no progression. Then I changed my onc, and she ordered a PET scan which showed a low level of cancer activity only in one lobe of the liver (I have numerous mets throughout the whole liver, plus a tumour on my spine and one axillary mass). Seems that the chemo has largely "turned my cancer off" - for the moment at least. CT scans for the liver are I think hard to read, especially as they don't distinguish between active tumour and necrotic tissue. Don't be despondent. Listen to china. Sometimes it can take a little longer to get to where we want to be. Anne

The other said, "Be prepared to live for a long time." I find that I count up not down, and with great delight. Now fourteen months from diagnosis.I relish the thought of my two year anniversary. And three years. And four.And onwards and upwards! Anne

Posts.Title: I got Approved for SIRT!!!! soleil505 redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2012 01:23PM Lemonsoda wrote: I had the procedure done 5 weeks ago. Firstly they used imaging to help them block off the blood vessels using microscopically small instruments through the artery in my groin, so that the radioactive agent stays within the liver rather than leaking out to any other organs. Then two weeks later, the radioactive agent was put into the liver through the same artery in my groin. The radioactive beads then deliver radiation directly into the liver over a period of eight weeks or so. The whole liver was covered in one procedure. Scan in 2 weeks will show if any benefit. Not promising myself anything, but 5 year studies have shown great results.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 08:43AM Lemonsoda wrote: Hi Ann. So sorry to hear your news, but thought I'd mention what happened to me. My liver had been stable on Herceptin alone, then just one new liver lesion appeared. Rather than go for the chemo, I chose radiofrequency ablation, which demolished it. I think I made the right choice, as it was a relatively easy procedure with instant effect. I know it's a matter of personal opinion, but I do not want to use up chemo options too soon. Just for one new lesion which can be dealt with differently. You are also Her2+ so there are other back up options available to you as well which may keep the cancer in check - Tykerb, Perjeta and TDM1. My personal philosophy is, chemo depletes your body (and your options) quickly. If there is another option, try it first. When you really need the chemo, then grab it. Don't forget, RFA kept that liver lesion inactive for a whole year. RFA can be repeated whenever you need it. Love and support, Anne
